sn35.146:4.1: “Mendicants, I will teach you old action, new action, the cessation of action, and the practice that leads to the cessation of action.
sn35.146:4.2: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak. …
sn35.146:4.4: The eye is old action. It should be seen as produced by choices and intentions, as something to be felt.
sn35.146:4.6: mind is old action. It should be seen as produced by choices and intentions, as something to be felt.
sn35.146:4.9: The deeds you currently perform by way of body, speech, and mind: this is called new action.
sn35.146:4.10: And what is the cessation of action?
sn35.146:4.11: When you experience freedom due to the cessation of deeds by body, speech, and mind: this is called the cessation of action.
sn35.146:4.12: And what’s the practice that leads to the cessation of action?
sn35.146:4.13: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
sn35.146:4.14: right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.
sn35.146:4.15: This is called the practice that leads to the cessation of action.
sn35.146:4.16: So, mendicants, I’ve taught you old action, new action, the cessation of action, and the practice that leads to the cessation of action.
sn35.146:4.17: Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do for the benefit of their disciples.
sn35.146:4.18: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts.
sn35.146:4.19: Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later!
sn35.146:4.21: This is my instruction to you.”
